Award.AwardTitle: The Nitrogen Fertilizer Industry: Integrating Industrial Ecology and Political Ecology Approaches

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will examine the synthetic nitrogen production industry by combining an industrial ecological focus on metabolism to trace inputs and outputs of the industrial process with a political ecology focus on politics, history, and culture to ascertain the complex relationships among natural and human systems. The project will consider the evolution and operation of a major economic sector from new perspectives. It will expand on the consideration of metabolism by moving beyond traditional considerations that focus on industrial process to consider inputs and outputs among a broader suite of natural and human systems, thereby permitting consideration of the role of natural systems in terms of impacting on and receiving outputs from industrial processes. The project will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the processes though which atmospheric nitrogen has been transformed into a commodity as well as they ways in which this economic enterprise has evolved and interacted with various natural and human systems. The project therefore will expand knowledge about the role of social and other human factors in the transformation of global biogeochemical flows. The project is expected to result in a range of products that will enhance fundamental theoretical understandings and yield practical benefits. A book and other publications will be disseminated to groups like the Fertilizer Institute, the Food and Agriculture Organization, The Earth Institute, the Center for Industrial Ecology, and the National Coalition for Sustainable Agriculture among other organizations in civil society and industry, The investigators also will develop special educational materials, including teaching modules that deal with the social and natural aspects of the nitrogen cycle and illustrate the technical process of taking fossil fuel and creating nitrogen fertilizer in industrial facilities as well as the larger relationships this industry has with society and the environment.

Scientists consider the "Haber-Bosch Process" of synthetic nitrogen production to be one of the most fundamental innovations of the 20th century. The process revolutionized global food production by lifting previous limitations on natural sources of nitrogen fertilizer, usually manure. The process has several sustainability concerns, however, because of its reliance on nonrenewable inputs, especially natural gas, water pollution, and excessive flows of nutrients into water bodies that can lead to eutrophication and phenomena like marine "dead zones." The process also yields significant levels of carbon emission and raises thorny questions regarding relationships between levels of food production and population growth. As such, nitrogen cuts across the energy-water-food nexus of environmental challenges. The investigators will combine an "input-output" analysis more traditionally employed in industrial ecology with a three-step research design focused on the historical and social dynamics of the primary "input" (natural gas), the industrial and related processes occurring at a representative site (Donaldsonville, Louisiana), and the primary "outputs" (nitrogen fertilizer and carbon dioxide). They will employ a range of methodological approaches, including archival research, interviews, and field-based observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Grant has already resulted in significant outcomes. I have published five articles (either in print or accepted) in peer reviewed journals that emerged from the research, including Geography’s flagship journal, The Annals of the American Association of Geographers (articles listed below). These articles were made possible by NSF funds. They emerged from (a) interviews with industry personnel, community leaders and environmental activists around nitrogen factories in Salina, Ontario and southern Louisiana in December 2013, Spring 2015, and Summer 2015; (b) industry representatives at a nitrogen industry conference in Savannah, GA in Fall 2014; (c) industry spokespeople at the Fertilizer Institute in Summer 2015; (d) Conversations with grant Senior Personnel Jesse Bond (chemical engineering at Syracuse) in the Summer of 2014. I have collected significant archival data on three trips (in August 2014, January 2016, and December 2016) that still remains almost entirely unused. This data will form the basis of a book project  on WW II and the development of the nitrogen industry (data analysis will occur during a semester leave in Fall 2017). This research has also led to several presentations at Conferences (the 2015 Dimensions of Political Ecology Conference and the 2016 AAG conference) and two invited lectures (one a keynote address at the Banff Research in Culture June 2016, with special focus, “On Energy”; and an invited talk at the University of Alberta in Fall 2016). 

 

I also published a webpage (funds helped me hire a web designer): unequalcarbonfootprints.org. The website allows individuals to compare their own carbon footprint with large industrial facilities (including the nitrogen ammonia factories, which are the subject of my NSF research). I announced this website on several academic listservs in March 2017 and received lots of positive feedback including several people who pledged to use the website in their courses. 

Articles in print or accepted.

 

1)      Huber, M.T. 2017. Hidden Abodes: Industrializing Political Ecology, Annals of the American Association of Geographers, 107(1): 151-166

DOI: 10.1080/24694452.2016.1219249

 

This article argues that political ecologists have not paid sufficient attention to industrial secondary manufacturing ecologies. It argues that such contexts might shift what constitutes both “politics” and “ecology” in the field.  It draws from interviews and fieldwork in and among a nitrogen factory in Southern Louisiana. This article was chosen as an “editor’s choice” and given free open access for 3 months between 2016 and 2017.

 

2)      Huber, M. T. 2017. Value, Nature, and Labor: A Defense of Marx. Capitalism, Nature, Socialism, 28(1): 39-52

DOI: 10.1080/10455752.2016.1271817

 

This article is part of a special issue on “Value in Capitalist Natures” (one of the cutting edge concepts and debates in political ecology today). It uses examples from the nitrogen fertilizer industry to argue Marx’s theory of value under capitalism can still be useful for understanding ecological degradation (as well as larger issues of nature-society relations). 

 

3)      Huber, M.T in press. Reinvigorating Class in Political Ecology: Nitrogen Capital and the Means of Degradation. Geoforum (pp. 1-8).

DOI: /10.1016/j.geoforum.2017.01.010


This article is part of a special issue on “Political Industrial Ecology” – a burgeoning field that bridges economic geography, industrial ecology and political ecology. This article argues that understanding unequal responsibility for climate change requires a “class” perspective focused on who controls the means of production (or what I call the means of ecological degradation). The article suggests class has fallen out of use in political ecology and needs reinvigoration. The article draws from fieldwork and interviews at nitrogen factories as well as industry conferences and think tanks.

 

4)      Huber, M.T. in press. Chemical dialectics. Geohumanities

 

This is a short 1,000 word essay is part of a larger “compendium” piece on “Chemical Geographies” (featuring five author prominent authors in political ecology). It emerged from a panel discussion at the 2016 AAG. My contribution relies heavily on conversations with NSF grant senior personnel Jesse Bond (chemical engineering at Syracuse) who taught me about the thermodynamics and equilibrium equations associated with ammonia synthesis reactions that take place at nitrogen factories. I argue for a “dialectical” or process-based analysis to understand both the physical and social aspects of this chemical reaction.

 

5)      Huber, M.T. and J. McCarthy. In press. Beyond The Subterranean Energy Regime? Fuel, Land-Use, and The Production of Space. Transactions of the Institute of British Geographers

 

This article was written during the research for this project. Examining the nitrogen fertilizer industry’s relationship with natural gas allowed me to think about the larger relationship between energy and subterranean (underground) energy resources. Prior to the fossil fuel age, energy was land-based (e.g. forests, feed for working animals) and this had important geographical consequences. These spatial dynamics must be considered when envisioning a post-carbon energy transition to renewables (the subject of recent research by James McCarthy from Clark University who is coauthor).
